Award.AwardTitle: SCH: EXP: Cost Efficient Osteoporosis Analysis using Dental Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates low-cost osteoporosis prescreening methods using dental data, which are collected during routine dental examination and thus at no additional cost. In particular, when a senior citizen attends the dental office for routine treatment, the proposed methods assess the evidence of osteoporosis based on collected data such as dental radiographs. The senior citizen is referred to a formal osteoporotic examination if high risk is found. Towards this goal, the project conducts three major research activities including systematical validation of the relation between dental data and bone quality measurement, dental image-based osteoporosis analysis, and integration of longitudinal and categorical information for osteoporosis prescreening. Decrease in bone quality causes major health problems in the United States. In particular, it has been estimated that osteoporosis afflicts 55% of Americans aged 50 and above. Early diagnosis of osteoporosis requires routine examination since no obvious symptom is associated with diagnosis before serious consequences, e.g., bone fracture, happen. Such routine examination can cause a big economic burden, since the data used in the current gold standard (i.e., dual energy X-ray absorptiometry) is not cost efficient to collect.

This project develops image analysis and machine learning methods for low-cost osteoporosis prescreening methods using dental data. The research advances science in both computational and clinical fields. In particular, it serves as an exemplary model of using routinely collected dental data for low-cost smart health assessment. Moreover, the specific techniques exploited or invented in this project can be easily generalized to other related clinical and non-clinical domains. In addition, the data analytics algorithms can be of general interest in many areas of science and engineering such as computer vision, medical image analysis, data mining, climate evolution, etc. The education activities of the project are tightly integrated with the research activities, by training and teaching students of different levels, disseminating research results to general audience, and involving under-represented students in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Known as the most common bone disease, osteoporosis has been estimated to afflict 55% of Americans aged 50 and above. Early diagnosis of osteoporosis requires routine examination since no obvious symptom is associated with diagnosis before serious consequences, e.g., bone fracture, happen. Such routine examination can unfortunately cause a big economic burden, since the data used in the current gold standard (i.e., dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA)) is cost inefficient to collect.

Motivated by the observation in dental research that bone quality degradation often causes changes in dental imagery, this project investigates low-cost osteoporosis prescreening methods using dental data, which are collected during routine dental examination and thus at no additional cost. In particular, when a senior citizen attends the dental office for routine treatment, the imagery data taken during the examination can be used for osteoporotic analysis. The senior citizen will then be referred to a formal osteoporotic examination if high risk was found.

Toward this goal, the project first confirms the correlation between osteoporotic status with dental image patterns. The modality tested is dental cone beam computational tomography (CBCT). On a CBCT dataset involving subjects from different gender-age groups, the investigation shows that trabecular features extracted from CBCT not only significantly correlate with gender-age labels, but also can be effectively combined with modern machine learning tools for high accurate gender-age classification. According to the established correlation between gender-age and bone quality, the result encourages the exploration of using dental images for osteoporotic analysis.

Then, moving forward using more common and inexpensive dental imagery, dental panoramic radiograph (DPR), the project studies on a DPR dataset with clinically validated osteoporotic status via DEXA scan. In particular, modern machine learning techniques are employed to develop DPR-based osteoporosis prescreening methods. First, a conventional (i.e., non-deep learning) model is trained and produces prescreening accuracy around 67.59%, which is encouragingly better than random guess on the dataset. Then, a deep neural network is developed that significantly boosts the accuracy to 89.81%. Finally, by addressing the issue of insufficient training data, a further improved deep model is constructed to leverage related tasks, and it achieves an accuracy of 92.59. These results show the great potential of applying modern machine learning tools and computer vision techniques for cost-efficient osteoporosis prescreening. Moreover, the project also investigates related problems such as region of interest (ROI) localization and cell tracking in biomedical images, as well as general computer vision algorithms.

Being an interdisciplinary research project, it naturally brings broader impact to different scientific areas. The core outcomes described above generate direct impacts to dental research, bone research, orthopedic research, machine learning and computer vision. Over twenty papers have been published in research journals or conference proceedings spreading the above mentioned areas. Moreover, around 10 students at different levels, ranging from high school volunteers to PhD students, have involved in the research and been trained successfully for their career preparation.
